Paying for College

Since all service members are encouraged to pursue higher education, the military has a variety of programs to help students pay for it.

Tuition Support Programs

  • Tuition Assistance: This program provides service members the opportunity to enroll in courses at accredited colleges, universities, junior colleges, and vocational-technical schools while they're serving. It can pay for up to 100% of the cost of tuition or expenses.
  • Post-9/11 GI Bill: Veterans wishing to further their education can use the Post-9/11 GI Bill to pay for tuition, living expenses, books, and supplies.
  • College Fund Programs: Also known as the GI Bill "kicker," these programs offer an additional amount of money that can be added to the Post-9/11 GI Bill.
  • Loan Repayment Programs: The Army and Navy offer loan repayment programs that help enlisted personnel pay off college loans accrued prior to service.
  • Community College of the Air Force: CCAF is an accredited two-year college open to enlisted Air Force men and women.
  • Army University: The Army University integrates all of the professional military education institutions within the Army into a single educational structure modeled after many university systems across the country. The Army University ensures Soldiers obtain credit for accomplished military experience, education, and training.
  • Testing Programs: Academic exams can earn service members college credit for skills acquired during military training and operations.
Learn More

Educational Institutions

  • Service Academies, Military Colleges, and Maritime Colleges: These are very competitive institutions of higher education that are virtually free to those that are accepted. After graduation, students serve as an officer for five years.
  • ROTC: Reserve Officer Training Corps programs provide officer training for students during college in exchange for scholarship money. In return, the students commit to serving for a set period of time after graduation.
